narrative:
As I sat down to tackle my 2023 taxes, I couldn't help but think about the miles I had put on my trusty old sedan. Between driving to client meetings and shuttling around the city for work events, my vehicle had been my faithful companion all year. I decided to take a closer look at my records to see if I had enough documentation to claim the standard mileage rate for business use of a vehicle. A quick check revealed that the standard mileage rate for 2023 was 65.5 cents per mile, which seemed like a reasonable estimate considering the rising cost of fuel and maintenance.

I remembered keeping a log throughout the year to track my business and personal use miles, which would come in handy for calculating my business use percentage. According to my records, I had driven a total of 12,000 miles in 2023, with 8,000 miles dedicated to business use. This worked out to a business use percentage of approximately 66.7%. Given that my vehicle was used for more than 50% business purposes, I decided to claim the standard mileage rate for my business use miles. Using this rate, I was able to calculate my deduction as 8,000 miles x 65.5 cents per mile, which came out to a tidy $5,240.

I was relieved to have a clear and straightforward solution for my vehicle expense deduction. I made a mental note to continue keeping my log up to date in 2024, as the standard mileage rate was increasing to 69.6 cents per mile. This would give me a chance to take advantage of the higher rate and potentially claim an even larger deduction. With my vehicle expense deduction squared away, I felt more confident and prepared to tackle the rest of my taxes.

facts.content: The standard mileage rate for business use of a vehicle is 65.5 cents per mile for 2023 and 69.6 cents for 2024.
Actual expenses for business use of a vehicle may include depreciation, but only if the vehicle is used for 50% or more business purposes.
To determine the business use percentage, add a log or calendar to keep track of business and personal use miles.
If you choose the standard mileage rate, you may not deduct actual expenses for gas, maintenance, and repairs.
If you choose the actual expense method, you must keep accurate records of total miles driven to determine the business use percentage.
